image.altText: An older woman with a dark grey bob and glasses speaks into a small microphone in front of a blue screen.

items.synopsis: Student protesters interrupt the beginning of a speech by incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock, taking issue with her past comment about needing to see the unemployment rate rise.

title.children: 'That's not what I thought was going to happen': Protesters interrupt incoming RBA boss over unemployment comments

image.altText: Mechelle wears a top with an Indigenous pattern as she speaks at an official police press conference

items.synopsis: Mechelle Turvey starts delivering training sessions to police recruits that she hopes will help them be more sensitive when dealing with victims of crime. WARNING: This story features the name and image of a deceased Aboriginal person.

title.children: 'I choose not to hate': Mother of Indigenous schoolboy Cassius Turvey delivering 'raw' training to police recruits

image.altText: Indigenous man Ken Wyatt wearing a white button-down shirt and a tie with and Indigenous pattern. Speaking at press conference.

items.synopsis: Former federal Liberal Indigenous affairs minister Ken Wyatt calls on party members to put politics aside and speak out in support of the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Liberal Party members urged to be 'brave' and vote Yes in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Madison is holding a binder and smiling.

items.synopsis: As cost-of-living pressures continue to climb, people are looking for creative ways to save. One method gaining popularity on social media is called "cash stuffing". It's a reinvention of the old envelope system our grandparents used to use, and it's bringing back the use of physical cash.

title.children: Madison says she'll never use her card full-time again after discovering 'cash stuffing'

image.altText: A close-up photo shows an older man with orange-tinged skin speaking loudly into a microphone at a rally.

items.synopsis: Mr Trump says he will appeal a trial date set the day before Super Tuesday. It's just the latest legal hurdle faced by the former president as he campaigns for the White House while battling multiple criminal and civil cases.

title.children: Donald Trump is facing 91 criminal charges and a range of civil lawsuits. Here's how his legal problems are lining up

image.altText: A tabby cat lies sleeping on a bookshelf with its head resting on a book.

items.synopsis: The RSPCA appeals for information over the "wicked, cowardly and callous" drowning of a beloved pet cat in the Swan River in Perth's east. WARNING: This article contains details that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Tiger Tim's owners spent two weeks desperately searching for him, but he had been deliberately drowned in a river

image.altText: A woman with short brown hair wearing a black and red patterned blazer mid-sentence on a stage pointing her finger.

items.synopsis: Virgin Australia boss Jayne Hrdlicka has called on the federal government to rethink its decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights to Australia, saying more flights would cut airfares by up to 40 per cent.

title.children: Virgin Australia boss says more Qatar Airways flights would lower airfares

image.altText: A composite image of John Marquis Hopkins and James Hayward.

items.synopsis: Convicted of child sex abuse, James Hayward is only the second MP in Western Australia's history, and the first in more than a century, to be removed from office for criminal activity. Here's what happens next.

title.children: Not since 1910 has WA’s parliament seen anything like the James Hayward scandal

image.altText: A worm in a specimen pot

items.synopsis: In a world first, doctors have extracted a living roundworm usually found in carpet pythons, from a patient's brain. They believe the infection occurred after the patient ate contaminated native greens.

title.children: 'Get it out of my hands right now': Surgeon removes living roundworm from patient's brain

image.altText: A scan of a brain and worm.

items.synopsis: Headlines about brain worms can be alarming but this is an extremely rare event. There are, however, plenty of more common parasites which can infect your body and brain, writes Vincent Ho.

title.children: Brain worms, tapeworms, amoebas: Inside the parasitic world that can affect your brain

image.altText: A woman in a sea of protesters holds a placard that reads "Not all men but too many"

items.synopsis: The women of the World Cup displayed nothing but merit. Extraordinary feats of skill. Flawless sportsmanship. Good behaviour on and off the pitch. They generated millions of new eyeballs for the beautiful game. And yet, they were overshadowed again and again by second-rate blokes, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It's a classic tale of meritorious women overshadowed by second-rate blokes

image.altText: A steelworks site with gas pipe flame flare, sky with scattering of clouds, dusk.

items.synopsis: The Federal Court fines BlueScope for engaging in cartel conduct over the supply of a product that is an essential material for builders, manufacturers and the automotive industry.

title.children: BlueScope fined a record $57.5 million over attempted price fixing that could have affected millions of consumers

image.altText: Several adult whales surrounded by numerous calves, as seen from above.

items.synopsis: A researcher says the reason for the decline is a mystery, but she hopes next year's survey reflects the results of a strong breeding season.

title.children: Southern right whale numbers have plunged on southern coast, census finds

image.altText: A young man sitting on his desk.

items.synopsis: The City of Gold Coast councillor accused of killing his stepfather could be released as early as next week, as lawyers call for him to be placed into protective custody while awaiting his bail hearing.

title.children: Gold Coast councillor Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden to seek early bail on murder charge

image.altText: People walking into the airport after arriving on a Qantas jet.

items.synopsis: There are concerns increasing numbers of fly-in fly-out workers will destroy the "social fabric" of Kalgoorlie-Boulder as BHP moves forward with plans for a large-scale mining camp in the city.

title.children: Kalgoorlie council backs BHP plan for 1,100-bed mining camp

image.altText: Woman holding baby with head turned away

items.synopsis: Essie Mitchell first spoke to her GP about a lump in her breast when she was 22. But it took 11 years and three more visits before her cancer was finally picked up, by which time it was too late to operate.

title.children: Mum's devastating diagnosis comes too late despite years of tests

image.altText: Missing man Michael Jeffrey Purse.

items.synopsis: The family of Adelaide man Michael Purse, whose remains have never been found after he was declared missing in April 2019, learn "brutal" details about his death while confronting two men who have pleaded guilty to his manslaughter.

title.children: Family of Michael Purse confront his killers in court, reject letter of apology

image.altText: A composite image of the leaders of the Labor, Liberal and Greens parties.

items.synopsis: The independent tribunal that sets politician pay has determined to give federal MPs a 4 per cent pay rise, saying previous pay increases have been conservative.

title.children: PM's pay bumped to $586k, Dutton's to $417k as salary increases for federal politicians rolled out

image.altText: Pakistan's former prime minister Imran Khan sits on a couch pointing in the air

items.synopsis: Khan was imprisoned on August 5 for unlawfully selling state gifts during his tenure as prime minister.

title.children: Pakistan ex-PM Imran Khan's graft conviction suspended by High Court, says lawyer

image.altText: A group of Aboriginal men and women standing and sitting on a red patch of dirt in front of a small sign

items.synopsis: After more than a decade of negotiations, Broken Hill's Wilyakali people have had a native title claim officially recognised by the federal court. The claim expands from the Barrier Ranges in New South Wales' far west over the border into South Australia.

title.children: Wilyakali people recognised as traditional owners of large patch of South Australian and NSW land

image.altText: A woman holding a TEMU bag

items.synopsis: A flashy new online shopping app has been bombarding Australians on social media. While some see it as the saviour of China's economy, not everyone is convinced.

title.children: TEMU might seem too good to be true. But the super-cheap Chinese app wants to dominate the world

image.altText: Custody photo of an Aboriginal man, staring directly into the camera.

items.synopsis: Earlier this month prosecutors downgraded a murder charge to manslaughter, prompting Warrick Walkerbear to plead guilty, foregoing the need for a Supreme Court trial.

title.children: Prison escapee to be sentenced in November for killing Kimberley woman

image.altText: Three men in business suits walk outside a large court building, two of them carrying documents under their arms.

items.synopsis: Ho Keun Shin — who subjected women to what a magistrate called "underhanded secretive abuse" during medical examinations, including at one of Adelaide's biggest hospitals — avoids jail and is instead handed a good behaviour bond.

title.children: Breast surgeon who indecently filmed women with recording device in tissue box avoids jail

image.altText: American sprinter Noah Lyles holds up three fingers and yells after a race at the athletics world championships.

items.synopsis: After more than a century, US athletics superstar Noah Lyles is within his rights to be sick of teams being dubbed "world champions" for winning American sporting leagues, writes Jon Healy.

title.children: 'That ain't the world': Why this US sprint star is copping flak from NBA stars who call themselves 'world champions'

image.altText: Silhouette of two Russian women standing close with a Russian flag and a Ukrainian flag

items.synopsis: Katya and Sascha know that speaking out against the war is risky, but that's not stopping them.

title.children: In Russia, the *** symbol has a huge meaning. This is why

image.altText: Margot winks at the camera as she claps in the air while wearing a gold glittery jumpsuit.

items.synopsis: Come on Barbie, lets go break some box office records in the US and internationally.

title.children: Barbie topples Harry Potter to become Warner Bros' highest-grossing film of all time

image.altText: picture of a man holding a metal bucket sitting in a football stadium behind the goal post

items.synopsis: Alex Agelopoulos, who injured a goalkeeper with a bucket when Melbourne Victory fans violently stormed AAMI Park, was released on bail after his lawyer immediately appealed the three-month jail term he was handed.

title.children: 'Bucket man' handed jail sentence over violent pitch invasion at Melbourne A-League game

image.altText: Actors Greta Lee and Teo Yoo sit on a ferry in the film Past Lives.

items.synopsis: Song's debut film, Past Lives, which has received critical acclaim, explores the connections made between people and the yearning for paths not travelled.

title.children: Celine Song explores 'destined connection' in tender directorial debut Past Lives

image.altText: A large set of drones is pictured inside a big warehouse-like space.

items.synopsis: There are five key observations which can be made about drones from their use in the war in Ukraine. And the Australian Defence Force needs to take notice, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: A 44-day conflict was a sign of what was to come in Ukraine. Now we know drones are changing warfare

image.altText: Vials with blood samples

items.synopsis: A new study suggests the early detection of lung, breast, prostate and colorectal cancers has only a small effect on our life span but Australian experts say the tests are based on solid evidence and save lives.

title.children: Cancer screening tests are commonplace, but how much benefit do they provide?

image.altText: A male tennis player in a blue shirt, holdsn his arms up in victory, with a racquet in one hand.

items.synopsis: Djokovic wasted no time in a match that started around 11pm local time, defeating Frenchman Alexandre Müller in straight sets 6-0, 6-2, 6-3.

title.children: Novak makes winning start to US Open, will reclaim world number one ranking

image.altText: A Belgian cyclist sits up in the saddle and raises his fist in the air in celebration after crossing the finish line.

items.synopsis: Belgian cycling star and defending champion Remco Evenepoel is losing patience with La Vuelta's safety measures, as he crashes into the crowd seconds after winning stage three and is left bleeding heavily.

title.children: 'It's breaking my balls now': Remco Evenepoel left bloody from post-race crash in latest incident at chaotic La Vuelta

image.altText: People gather around a huge flower with ruffles leaves around a tall central spike.

items.synopsis: Visitors are flocking to a library near Los Angeles to view a giant corpse flower giving off an almighty stink during a rare blooming period which only comes about once every few years.

title.children: 'Like an urban dumpster': Rare corpse flower stinks out Californian library
